title: Removed per client/server specific acquire/release and consolidated them in one place
body: In-order to remove the excessive cost of new/deletes of the google protobuf objects, Heron introduced protobuf pool in https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1421. This implementation relied on a per client/server proto pool implemented as part of the Server/Client classes. While this improved performance, it's drawback was that the proto pools were per client/server specific. Thus if say a stmgr connects with two remote stmgrs, each client would have its own proto pool. This is a) unnecessary and b) suboptimal because varying traffic patterns means that while some protopools could grow fast and could remain unused later on, others might see traffic increases and might have to resort to doing new/deletes cater for the increased traffic. This results in suboptimal performance and increased memory usage. This pr solves that by making a single unified protopool that everyone shares across.

title: update stmgr max packet size
body:
When the stmgr receives a packet with large size but less than max()-1, the memory alloc get stuck in the `IncomingPacket::Read(int)`

```
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007f239971443d in write () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#1  0x0000000000408867 in (anonymous namespace)::ReportLargeAlloc (num_pages=num_pages@entry=145963, result=result@entry=0x7a9a000) at src/tcmalloc.cc:1023
#2  0x00000000004089b0 in (anonymous namespace)::do_malloc_pages (heap=<optimized out>, size=1195728896, size@entry=1195725856) at src/tcmalloc.cc:1083
#3  0x000000000058b3da in do_malloc_no_errno (size=1195725856) at src/tcmalloc.cc:1110
#4  cpp_alloc (nothrow=false, size=1195725856) at src/tcmalloc.cc:1434
#5  tc_newarray (size=1195725856) at src/tcmalloc.cc:1642
#6  0x000000000049aa58 in IncomingPacket::Read(int) ()
#7  0x000000000049783e in Connection::readFromEndPoint(int) ()
#8  0x0000000000492e99 in BaseConnection::handleRead(EventLoop::Status) ()
#9  0x00000000004992dd in EventLoopImpl::handleReadCallback(int, short) ()
#10 0x00000000004a2f4c in event_process_active_single_queue (activeq=0x1af0020, base=0x1b08000) at event.c:1350
#11 event_process_active (base=<optimized out>) at event.c:1420
#12 event_base_loop (base=0x1b08000, flags=0) at event.c:1621
#13 0x00000000004090eb in main ()
```

The fix is to set max packet size according to config

title: Fix flakey HeronServerTest test
body:
I saw a test failure of `testHandleAccept` and `testSendMessage`. I think the first was because the test didn't wait for connect to happen, so there's a race. I've added a `CountDownLatch` for server connect to fix this. For the other issue the error was during `after()` when the server was being shutdown. It seems that the `client.stop()` method was being executed twice and the `OutputPacket` size went to zero after it was checked but before processing was attempted. title: start ckptmgr in heron_executor if topology is stateful
body:
This PR updates the heron_executor to start ckptmgr if the topology is stateful enabled. 
It also updates the schedulers to generate the new heron_executor cmd. 

Each scheduler is updated in a separate commit. For `LocalScheduler`, `Mesos Scheduler`, `Slurm Scheduler` and `YarnScheduler`, they share the util method in `SchedulerUtils` to generate the correct command. So they don't need special updates.

All unit test passed and local scheduler is tested.

title: Adding new HeronServerTester to simplify testing servers
body:
Adding `HeronServerTester` to simplify writing unit tests against Heron server. Much of what's in `HeronServerTester` is code that's copied in multiple tests.

Provides the following benefits:

- Consolidates common boilerplate client/server code that each unit test shouldn't have to deal with (loopers, threadpools, etc)
- Removes the use of timers and uses countdown latches instead. This reduces this test from 13 seconds to 1 second.
- Reduces possibility of flaky tests due to mis-implementation of sleep logic.
- Makes test logic easier to read and understand since other clutter is removed.

Review includes one test to show how `HeronServerTester` is used. I've upgraded one other that I'll do in a follow-up review. There will be a few more to upgrade after that.

title: Fix heron/common targets to be mutually exclusive
body:
There was a bug in how the targets in `heron/config/java/src/BUILD` were organized in that the following existed:

`basics` -> `c.t.h.common.basics`
`config` -> `c.t.h.common.config`
`network` -> `c.t.h.common.network`
`common` -> `c.t.h.common.{basics,config,network,utils}`

A few issues with this:
1. Classes in `c.t.h.common.{basics,config,network}` are all included in two bundles. It's best practice for a class should only ever exist in one.
2. All deps in `c.t.h.common.{basics,config,network}` bleed into the `common` target, making it so that the more granular targets can't easily stand on their own.
3. It's not possible to only depend on `c.t.h.common.{utils}`, but you can depend on only one of `c.t.h.common.{basics,config,network}`.

This changes makes it so we have a target/bundle for each part of common:
`basics` -> `c.t.h.common.basics`
`config` -> `c.t.h.common.config`
`network` -> `c.t.h.common.network`
`utils` -> `c.t.h.common.utils`

title: Use Duration to represent durations of time instead of primatives
body:
Instead of using ints and long to represents nanoseconds, milliseconds, seconds and minutes, we should use Duration. This makes units clear and removes the need for unit conversion math.

Apologies for the large review but there were a number of cascading effects. The main goal was to:

- Convert all time duration configs in `SystemConfig` to use `java.time.Duration`
- Remove all possible date math and the conversion constants in `c.t.h.basics.Constants`

There are still places where we use `long` to represent seconds since the epoch for some local calculations, which is fine. From an API perspective though, wherever we pass around time-based durations we should use the `Duration` class. This make unit unambiguous.

title: add 'heron' prefix to all heron client optional args
body:
One of our user failed to deploy his topology with the following cmd

```
heron submit dc/role/env ${TOPO_FILE} ${TOPO_CLASS} --config ${TOPO_CONF} --env staging --topology_id 1
```

The error message shows:
```
usage: heron submit [options] cluster/[role]/[env] topology-file-name topology-class-name [topology-args]
heron submit: error: ambiguous option: --config could match --config-path, --config-property
```

It turns out the user's topology takes an argument named "config" which caused the client confusion and failed the submission. 

Since this use case is common, the "heron" prefix is added to optional argument to avoid such conflicts. And this is also how the optional arguments named in the old internal heron client.

title: fix aurora to use maximum resources to start containers
body:
`getRequiredResource()` returns the amount of minimum resource needed by each container generated by packing plan, while `getScheduledResource()` returns the maximum resource among all of them.

To start a aurora container with enough resource, `scheduled resource` should be used. If `required resource` is used, there's a chance that aurora container doesn't reserve enough rams. Containers get  out of memory error and are restarted constantly.

This change is tested with actual topologies within twitter environment.

title: Stream subprocess stdout and stderr in heron-executor
body:
The logs for subprocesses launched by the heron-executor were
not actually streamed to the heron-executor log file. Using
`communicate` to read the output of a subprocess will wait until the
process is closed before actually reading the logs. In the non-blocking
case the stdout and stderr were sent to a pipe but were not actually
read from which results in a deadlock if the subprocess logs enough
information into the stderr buffer
([python docs on subprocess and
pipes](https://docs.python.org/2/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.check_call)).

> Do not use stdout=PIPE or stderr=PIPE with this function as that can
deadlock based on the child process output volume.

Heron uses glog to log messages to a file however zookeeper defaults to
using stderr with no easy way to tell it to use glog instead. As such
whenever zookeeper logged a message it would get written to the
subprocess stderr buffer and fill it up ultimately causing a deadlock in
the zookeeper thread in the tmaster trying to write to stderr. This then
manifests itself by the zookeeper client not being able to heartbeat and
having its session expire without being able to callback and restart the
process.

With `subprocess.communicate` the data is [buffered in
memory](https://docs.python.org/2/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.Popen.communicate) until end-of-line is reached
and the subprocess is terminated so it is not suitable for long running processes.

One design consideration here for simplicity is the redirection of the
subprocess stderr to stdout. This is to make reading the data easier.
The downside here is that it is not possible to tell if a log message
came from stdout or stderr but I think that information will be clear
with the content of the message. Also some dependencies like zookeeper
log all of their messages on stderr anyway regardless of the message
type.

Fixes https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/1653

title: Fail Heron-instance fast for errors
body:
Currently heron-instance will try best-effort to clean the resources,
when uncaught exceptions happen. However, if it meets an error, for instance,
"java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space", any consequent operations are not guaranteed to be done,
and it can lead the process to a bad state, for instance, hanging forever.

This pull request fixes it by making heron-instance fail fast for errors. And this issue is raised by ADs team from Twitter.

Tested with LocalScheduler.

title: Properly shade + POM heron-api.jar and heron-storm.jar
body:
This PR includes multiple fixes, but its major purposes are:
1. properly shade `heron-api.jar` (`//heron/api/src/java:heron-api`) and `heron-storm.jar` (`//heron/storm/src/java:heron-storm`)
2. Kryo dependency will be specified in POM file, instead of being linked into the fatjar

To verify Kryo is not linked into these two jars, one can use `jar tf` and `grep` to verify.

This two fixes make Twitter internal tests pass when we switch to OSS Heron.

Minor fixes include:
1. Examples now use `org.apache.storm` instead of `backtype`. The missing `GlobalMetrics` is added under `heron/storm`.
2. `heron-storm.jar` [will only include `org.apache.storm.***`](https://github.com/twitter/heron/compare/master...objmagic:no-fat-jar?expand=1#diff-cf85344880ea3bb51b03100c97fb7a82R23)
3. Removed some unused protobuf build targets.

Some other notes:
1. Guava dependency is not touched at all. It is linked into jars and is shaded. It is trivial that we can remove Guava dependency from `heron-api.jar`, but this is not the case for `heron-storm.jar`. `heron-storm.jar` depends on Simulator, which further depends on lots of libraries that are using Guava. Thus we decide not to remove Guava.

Also attached are `heron-api.jar` and `heron-storm.jar`. Please feel free to use `jar tf` to examine their contents. 

[heron-api-and-heron-storm.zip](https://github.com/twitter/heron/files/945500/heron-api-and-heron-storm.zip)
